headline: No-Fuss Perfect Baked Brown Rice
description: This versatile recipe gives you fluffy, tender brown rice from the oven, a perfect way to keep your stovetop free for the main dish.
name: No-Fuss Perfect Baked Brown Rice

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x9 baking dish.
Place rice in prepared baking dish; sprinkle salt and oil on top. Pour boiling water over rice. Cover baking dish tightly with double layer of aluminum foil and pinch edges to seal.
Bake in center of preheated oven until water is absorbed, about 1 hour.
Remove rice from oven, uncover, and fluff with fork.

review.reviewBody:
This is so easy and forgiving. I was dreading making brown rice away from home where the rice cooker makes it simple. The rice produced with this recipe is better than I get from the rice cooker and cleanup is much quicker. That cooker may go to a new owner!

Add seasonings and vegetables to your liking and this could become a pilaf.
Nice change from steamed rice, fluffy not sticky and perfectly done.

Being inspired by Chef John’s Baked Fried Rice recipe - and my belief that perfectly cooked brown rice is more daunting to pull off - I was excited to try this! It IS good! Followed exact but used boiled chicken broth vs water. This does smell a little like popcorn! But even with extra foil and baked for an hour - while all liquid was absorbed, some bites were close to crunchy! Maybe add a TBLS of oil vs 2 tsp or a tad more liquid. I really liked this idea and it mostly turned out well but, for me & my oven, needs a slight modification. I’m so glad I tried and plan to play with to get the perfect brown rice!! Good starter base! Thank you!
GREAT!! Even the picky teenager liked it. We both agreed that it needed more flavor so we'll play with different seasonings.

This is a great method for cooking brown rice easily to the ideal consistency without taking up a burner on the stove or buying a rice cooker. It’s easy to tailor the seasonings to your tastes and for the meal you’re making. I make a smaller portion, using 1 cup rice and 1 3/4 cups broth. I use olive oil, a large smashed garlic clove, salt/pepper and herbs to complement whatever I’m making, and I add all that right in the broth while I boil it. I use cooking spray in the baking dish and just one layer of foil (don’t know why you need two). It’s been perfect 3 times now :)
I did not totally love the texture of the finished product. Flavor was good with the addition of chicken stock and garlic flakes.

I used a high grade olive oil instead of canola, used a teaspoon of classic pesto. instead of brown rice, I used Lundberg Wild Blend rice and one cup of Mahatma Jasmine rice. I used salt free Swanson's cooking stock-chicken. Cooked it for an hour, fluffed it and it's fabulous!

I have NEVER been able to make rice that wasn't sticky and gross despite numerous attempts, yet this recipe was a no-brainer. The rice came out fluffy, tender and delicious, it was also very forgiving. I initially forgot to cover the rice while baking and after an hour it was still uncooked, so I covered the dish tightly w/ foil and placed it back for another hour. Perfect!

This is an amazing way to cook rice. I've made this recipe three times now and I've been impressed every time. Last night I replaced the water with chicken broth because the pork chops my husband was making did not have a lot of sauce. Delicious! I don't think I'll ever cook rice on the stove top again.
